Khan a Chanchal Samanta d Rajaram Bal a b ⁎ a Light Stock Processing Division, CSIR- Indian Institute of Petroleum, Haridwar Road, Mohkampur, Dehradun 248005, India Light Stock Processing Division CSIR- Indian Institute of Petroleum Haridwar Road, Mohkampur Dehradun 248005 India aLight Stock Processing Division, CSIR- Indian Institute of Petroleum, Haridwar Road, Mohkampur, Dehradun 248005, India b Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad- 201002, India Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR) Ghaziabad 201002 India bAcademy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad- 201002, India c Science Block, Department of Chemistry, IIT(ISM) Dhanbad 826004, India Science Block Department of Chemistry IIT(ISM) Dhanbad 826004 India cScience Block, Department of Chemistry, IIT(ISM) Dhanbad 826004, India d Corporate R&D Centre, Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited, Greater Noida -201306, India Corporate R&D Centre Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited Greater Noida 201306 India dCorporate R&D Centre, Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited, Greater Noida -201306, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Upgradation of biomass derived furanic molecules viz. Furfural and 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) through transfer hydrogenation using cyclohexanol as a hydrogen donor agent over CuMgO-based catalyst is reported here. CuMgO (2–10 wt% Cu loading) based catalysts were synthesized through hydrothermal route and thoroughly investigated by XRD, SEM, TEM, ICP-AES, BET-surface area, XPS, H2-TPR and DFT calculation. 5 wt% CuMgO-5 (designated as CuMgO-5) catalyst exhibited very high catalytic activity (>99% conversion of reactant) in the transfer hydrogenation of furanic molecules to corresponding alcohols with ∼100% selectivity at 180 °C after 7 h of reaction. Catalytic experiments and detailed characterization of the catalyst indicate that high Cu dispersion and the presence of metallic Cu on the MgO surface are key parameters for its high catalytic activity. Furthermore, the kinetics studies showed that the reaction is sensitive with reaction temperature. DFT calculation reveals the endergonic process of H2 removal from cyclohexanol and the exergonic process of H2 addition to carbonyl group of furanic molecules. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Transfer hydrogenation Furanic molecules Cumgo nanostructured catalyst Cyclohexanol Introduction The continuous uses of fossil based resources such as coal, crude oil and natural gas for the production of energy, fuels and chemicals to fulfill the need of modern society have resulted adverse effect on the global environment and climate change. As a result, worldwide efforts are on to reduce carbon footprints from industrial activities and researchers all over the world are looking for finding alternative production routes for chemicals and fuels based on renewable resources for the development of carbon neutral circular and sustainable society [1,2] The unique source which is most sustainable present on the earth for organic carbon is biomass and due to its high-abundance and low-cost, it has received much attention for the production of valuable chemicals in recent days. The chemicals produced from biomass are considered as “green” alternatives of the corresponding petroleum based chemicals and have much lower carbon footprint. Biomass when undergoes several thermochemical and biological processes resulting to production of different types of molecules that are called platform molecules. The list of platform molecules was first set by the US Department of Energy (DOE) in 2004 and which was revised by Bozell et al. in 2010 [1–4]. The revised list included a vital class of furans, mainly furfural (FL) and 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) [5]. These furans play the role of intermediate chemical between biomass resources and value added chemicals derived from biomass [6,7]. These furans can be obtained from both hemicellulose and cellulose constituents of biomass [8–10]. Both the furans are multi-functionalized compounds and can be upgraded through hydrogenation of either C = O and/or C = C group simultaneously by various types of catalytic processes and the hydrogenation of both C = O and C = C group leads to the production of highly valuable chemicals [10–12]. Selective hydrogenation of the carbonyl group of FL and HMF results to their corresponding alcohols, which are widely used for the production of polymers, resins, corrosion-resistant mortar, carbon binder and other fine chemicals [13–16]. Although, there are several reports on the hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol (FLOL), but the selective hydrogenation of HMF to 2,5-bishydroxymethyl furan (BHMF) is rarely reported [17]. BHMF is a useful intermediate for the production of polymers, crown ethers, resins and artificial fibres. Highly selective control hydrogenation of HMF to 2,5-bishydroxymethyl furan (BHMF), where only aldehyde (–CHO) group undergoes hydrogenation to alcohol (-CHOH) group, is a major challenge, since HMF can undergoes subsequent ring hydrogenation or hydrogenolysis of –CHOH group favouring thermodynamically stable products such as 5 Methyl furfural, 5-methyl furfuryl alcohol (MFA), and 5-methyltetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (MTTHFA) [18,19]. Scheme 1 shows the hydrogenation pathways of furfural and HMF into their derivatives. For the selective reduction of both the furans, hydrogenation using molecular H2 catalysed by various metal supported catalysts such as Pt, Ir, Pd, Ni, Co, Cu, [16,20–25] has been reported. However, the use of molecular H2 lead to many challenges associated with storage and transportation of hydrogen and process safety [26]. Also, solubility of hydrogen in the reaction medium may limits the rate of liquid phase hydrogenation of FL and HMF and need costly high pressure operation. Recently, catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) route using liquid molecules such as methanol, ethanol, isopropanol, formic acid, cyclohexanol, etc. has been found as an interesting alternative to the hydrogenation of biomass derived molecules using molecular hydrogen for hydrogenation [9]. In this regard, alcohols severed as potential H-donor among different types of hydrogen donor [27]. Fu et al. carried out furfural (FL) hydrogenation to furfuryl alcohol (FLOL) using isopropanol as a hydrogen donor agent over nitrogen-doped iron-based catalyst supported on carbon and achieved 91.6% conversion of furfural with 83.0% selectivity for furfuryl alcohol [28]. Wang et al. also used isopropanol as a hydrogen donor over iron-based catalyst and obtained 91.7% yield of FLOL with 92.6% FL conversion [29]. Hermans et al. reported the effect of Cu, Ni and Pd metal on iron-supported catalyst for transfer hydrogenation of FL and HMF, where hydrogen was supplied by isopropanol, however with Cu, Ni-based catalyst, total FLOL and BHMF selectivity was ∼ 70%, whereas Pd-Fe2O3 catalyst showed over-hydrogenation products [9]. Vlachos et al. used Ru/C catalyst and 2-propanol as a hydrogen donor agent for hydrogenation of furfural but the main product was 2-methylfuran with 61% yield [30]. Marchi et al. studied Cu-Mg-Al catalyst for hydrogenation of furfural and obtained close to 100% furfural conversion. However, high conversion of furfural was due to high Cu loading (ca.40 wt%) in the catalyst and 2-propanol was used as hydrogen transfer agent [31]. Lu et al. had also investigated furfural hydrogenation using similar type of catalyst system [32]. Nagaraja et al. in 2007, first revealed the transfer hydrogenation of furfural using cyclohexanol as a hydrogen transfer agent over Cu/MgOCr2O3 catalyst. They used Cu-based catalyst with high loading of Cu (10–50 wt%) and higher reaction temperature (220 °C), however, yield of FLOL was ∼ 60% [13]. The same group also reported the effect of different promoters on Cu-MgO catalyst and observed that Cr is the most suitable additive in enhancing the yield of FLOL and cyclohexanone [33]. Use of cyclohexanol has major advantage over other secondary alcohols due to its useful dehydrogenation product, cyclohexanone, which is an important chemical used as a raw material for making Nylon 6,6 and Nylon 6 [34]. Although, Cu/MgO based catalysts showed good conversion of FL with good selectivity for FLOL but the presence of hazardous Cr limits the practical application of the catalyst from environmental point of view. It is reported that, addition of Cr increases the overall surface area and also can influence Cu metallic surface area of catalysts which are the key factors to boost the yield of FLOL. Therefore, high Cu metallic surface area of Cu/MgO catalysts is crucial to enhance conversion of FL and selectivity for FLOL. In our present study, we focused on developing high surface area Cu/MgO based catalysts with high Cu metallic surface area for low temperature selective hydrogenation reaction compare with available literature. This high surface Cu/MgO catalyst was used in the transfer hydrogenation of furanic compounds using cyclohexanol as a hydrogen transfer agent and found to be very active and selective for hydrogenation at lower (170–180 °C) temperature. Both Furfural and HMF were selectively hydrogenated into the corresponding alcohols (Scheme 1) over Cu/MgO catalyst under optimized reaction conditions. Experimental Materials & methods Magnesium ethoxide (99%), Copper chloride hydrate, (99 %), 5- hydroxymethyl furfural, furfural, furfuryl alcohol, were purchased from Sigma Aldrich Co. Cyclohexanol, Isopropyl alcohol, 2-butanol were purchased from Merck KGaA, Darmstadt, Germany. Ethylene glycol (99%) was purchased from Fisher Scientific. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Ethanol and double distilled water used for the washing of catalyst. Catalyst synthesis High surface area Cu-MgO catalyst was prepared using magnesium ethoxide and copper chloride dihydrate as source for Mg and Cu, respectively. 9.41 gm magnesium ethoxide was dissolved in 200 ml of ethylene glycol and ethanol mixture (1:1 ratio) in a 500 ml beaker under vigorous stirring. The stirring was continued till magnesium ethoxide dissolved completely to make the solution clear. Thereafter, 10 ml ethanol solution of 0.131 g of copper chloride dihydrate (for 5% Cu loading) was dropwise added into the clear solution of Mg salt. The aqueous ammonia solution (25% w/w) which work as a precipitating agent as well as reducing agent was added into Mg salt solution until pH reached in between 9 and 10 and stirring was continued further for 1 h. Finally, the resultant reaction mixture was transferred into 500 ml autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 24 h. The resulting material was filtered and washed with excess of ethanol and water. As-synthesized solid was then dried at 100 °C for 6 h and then grinded. In the next step, dried grinded powder material was calcined at 500 °C for 3 h. Based on Cu loading in the catalyst, material was designated as CuMgO-X (e.g. when Cu loading is 5 wt %, it is represented as CuMgO-5). Other Cu/MgO catalysts were prepared under similar procedure described above. Catalytic reactions Transfer hydrogenation of biomass derived furanic molecules The transfer hydrogenation reactions of FL and HMF were performed in a high-pressure batch reactor (Parr 4848) with essential controllers. Prior to every reaction the activation of catalyst (0.1 g) was done at 300 °C for 2 h in the flow of H2 (10% H2, balance N2). For a single run 1.0 g of FL or HMF, CuMgO-5 (0.1 g) and 20 ml of cyclohexanol were charged in the reactor and stirred for 10 min at normal temperature. The presence of air in the system was removed by purging with N2 twice and the vessel pressure was increased up to 3.0 MPa. Then the reactor was started to heat from room temperature to 180 °C. The reaction was carried out for 6 h, or depending on the experimental conditions. The aliquots of the reaction were collected through the sample valve connected within the reactor. After completion of the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and then the reactor pressure was released very slowly. The CuMgO-X particles were collected by centrifugation and the liquid solution was analysed by Thermo GC 700, with a Restek carbowax capillary column (30 m× 0.25 nm ID, 0.25 μm film thickness) and a FID detector. Identification of products were done by GC–MS (HP 5890 GC coupled with 5972 MSD). For the recyclability test collected catalyst form centrifugation was washed with water and ethanol and dried at 100 °C for 6 h. The presence of Cu concentration in the filtrate was confirmed by ICP analysis and found negligible (>2ppb). DFT method The DFT calculations of transfer hydrogenation reaction of furfuryl and cyclohexanol over Cu(111) were performed using the periodic plane-wave Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP 5.3.5) [35]. The surface of Cu(111) is modelled using four layered 6 × 4 supercell having a vacuum of 20 Å along the z-axis. Revised Perdew-Burke-Erbzerhof (RPBE) GGA exchange-correlation functional was used [36]. The A plane wave basis energy cut-off of 396 eV was used for expanding the Kohn–Sham one-electron valence states. The core-electrons were described using the Vanderbilt ultra-soft pseudopotentials [37]. The van der Walls dispersion corrections were incorporated using the Grimme DFT-D3 correction with Becke-Jonson damping [38]. The surface Brillouin zone is sampled using a 2 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst–Pack grid [39]. A energy and force convergence criteria have been set to 1 × 10–6 eV and 0.05 eV/Å, respectively, used for the geometry optimizations. The adsorption energy (Eads) of the surface intermediates were calculated as follows: (1) E a d s = E s u r f + a d s o r b a t e − ( E s u r f + E a d s o r b a t e , g a s ) where Esurf, Esurf+adsorbate, and Eadsorbate, gas denotes the energy of the clean Cu(111) surface, energy of adsorbate species on the Cu(111) surface and energy of adsorbate in gas-phase, respectively. The reaction energy (Erxn) of the elementary surface reaction steps is evaluated as the difference between final (product) and initial state (reactant) energies, as per the equation: (2) E r x n = E f i n a l − E i n i t i a l where Einitial and Efinal is the energy of the initial and final state of the elementary surface reaction step, respectively. Nudged Elastic Band (NEB) method as proposed by Henkelman et al. [40]. was used to obtain the transition state energies and geometries. In the NEB method the minimum energy path joining the reactant and the product is constructed with of 8 images between the initial and final states. The energy and force convergence criteria 1 × 10–4 eV and 0.1 eV/Å, respectively were used for the NEB calculations. Geometries of the transition state were determined using the climbing image NEB method [41]. For both the geometry optimizations and NEB calculations, the two bottom layers of the Cu(111) slab are fixed at their bulk positions, where the top two layers along with the adsorbates were allowed to relax. Activation barrier of the elementary reaction step is evaluated as the difference between the transition state and the reactant state, given by: (3) E r x n = E f i n a l − − E i n i t i a l Where ETS and Ereactant represents the energy of the transition state and reactant of the elementary step, respectively. Result and discussion The physico-chemical properties of as-synthesized Cu/MgO catalysts was summarized in Table 1 . It was found that BET surface area of Cu/MgO catalysts were lower as compared to bare MgO, when Cu was loaded on the surface of MgO. We believe that the formation of Cu clusters on the surface of MgO takes place which is responsible for blocking the pores of MgO species [42]. The H2 pulse chemisorption was carried out to calculate the dispersion of Cu species over MgO surface. The metal dispersion of 2.5% Cu-MgO catalyst was 29% and on increasing Cu loading, the dispersion slightly decreases to 27%, when Cu loading was 10%. The metallic surface area was also calculated and it was found that with the increase in metal dispersion value, the metallic surface area increased. Powder x-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-prepared Cu-MgO catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . The standard diffraction pattern (Fig. 1a) of Cu-free support reveals the high crystallinity and cubic phase of MgO with the characteristics peaks at 2 theta values of 37.1, 42.2, 48.8, 62.2, which is confirmed by JCPDS card 01–1235. When 5% copper was loaded (Fig. 1c) on the surface of MgO, XRD pattern of Cu/MgO is almost close to that of XRD patterns of MgO. It was observed that a peak intensity at 2 theta value of 37.2 was slightly increased (under blue box) when the loading of Cu was increased from 2.5 wt% to 10 wt% and this observation indicated the presence of Cu on the surface of MgO. We also noticed that the change in the intensity (under green box) with 2 theta value of 48.8 was observed. Chang et al. explained that the decrease in intensity is the cause of amorphous phase and random distribution of metal atom on crystal lattice [43]. Here, we assumed that the reduction in the peak intensity at 2 theta 48.8 is due to the random distribution of metallic Cu species over MgO crystal lattice. In case of reduced sample (Fig 1e) the intensity of metallic Cu was increased, and we believed that amount of metallic Cu increased on the surface of MgO resulting the increased peak intensity. The used catalyst (Fig. 1f) again showed the same intensity of the peak corresponds to metallic Cu° as H2 is generated during the dehydrogenation process. The representative TEM images (Fig 2 ) of CuMgO-5 catalyst depicted that average particle size of MgO species is around 20–30 nm. The Cu particles are well dispersed on the surface of MgO with the average size of ∼3 nm, which is also supported by H2 chemisorption analysis (Table 1). The clear lattice fringes shown in the inset image (Fig 2C) with a d-value of 0.189 nm which corresponds to the metallic Cu [111] plane with a diffraction angle of 43.6° is also presented in XRD. The SAED (selected area electron diffraction) pattern represented in Fig. 2d confirms the crystalline nature of Cu/MgO catalyst with diffraction planes for Cu and MgO, which are clearly visible. Uniform dispersion of Cu is shown in TEM elemental mapping (Fig 2). The SEM images given in Figure S2 (supporting information) shows the very thin flakes like morphology of catalysts and SEM elemental mapping confirms the well dispersion of Cu on MgO surface. The reducibility of Cu/MgO catalysts was estimated from H2 TPR analysis as shown in Fig. 3 . The reduction behaviour strongly depends on the metal support interaction and the particles size. The representative TPR profiles show two distinguished reduction bands in the temperature range 250–400 °C may be due to two different types of CuO particles. The lower and higher temperature reduction peaks attributed to the small and large CuO particles, respectively (Fig. 3) [42]. Another cause for high temperature reduction is the high metal support interaction, which is noticeable in 10% Cu loading (Fig 3 top line). The exceptional activity of 5% Cu loaded catalyst may be due to the presence of large number of small sized CuO species reduced at lower temperature [44]. The chemical state of prepared catalysts was characterized by XPS analysis. Fig. 4 represents the deconvoluted Cu2p XPS of fresh as well as spent catalyst. In the fresh catalyst, the main peaks for Cu2p3/2 exhibits in the range of binding energies value ∼935.2 eV, corresponding to the Cu2+ species. Metallic Cu peaks appear at ∼932.1 eV and there is no difference of binding energy between Cu1+ and metallic Cu. So, Cu LMM Auger spectra is taken to differentiate between Cu1+ and metallic Cu [45]. Similarly, the peak of Cu2p1/2 with binding energy 955.1 eV corresponds to presence of Cu2+. The difference of binding energy between Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2 is 19.9 eV, which is enough evidence to confirm that Cu in catalyst is in Cu2+ state (Fig 4A) [46]. The shake-up peak at 943.4 eV further confirms the Cu2+ oxidation state. These satellites were due to the charge transfer between the transition metal 3d and surrounding ligand oxygen 2p orbitals, and the spent catalyst also showed the absence of satellites in the spectra, confirmed that no considerable quantity of Cu2+ species is left on the surface. In case of spent catalyst the main peak of Cu2p3/2 shifted to the lower binding energy and there is no separate shake-up satellite peaks observed (Fig 4B). These observations indicate the change in the oxidation state of Cu from Cu2+ to /metallic Cu after catalysis [47]. In this reaction, evolution of H2 takes place which is responsible for the reduction of Cu2+ to metallic Cu moiety. The Fig 4 shows the Mg1s XPS spectra. In freshly prepared catalyst, the XPS peak at 1305 eV is ascribed to the presence of Mg2+in the form of MgO phase and the peak at 1302.9 eV also shows the presence of Mg2+ due to the presence of Mg(OH)2 (Fig 4a). However, in spent catalyst Mg2+ state is exclusively for MgO phase and there is no Mg(OH)2 found in the catalyst (Fig 4b) [48]. Survey scan of fresh and spent catalyst was also in Figure S1 (supporting information). The scan also confirms the presence of Mg, O, Cu and no other impurities are present on the surface. Catalyst activity Effect of reaction temperature The reaction was performed in the temperature range between 150 and 180 °C. The conversion of furanic molecules and cyclohexanol were found to depend strongly on the temperatures, where the conversion increases sharply with increasing temperature from 150 °C to 180 °C (Fig. 5 ). Although the conversion of furanic molecules was low (∼8 %) at 150 °C temperature but the selectivity of corresponding alcohols was 100%. As the reaction temperature increased from 150 to 180 °C, a linear trend of increasing conversion of both the furans molecules was observed. The maximum conversion of FL and HMF was 99% and 98% respectively at 180 °C. These results revealed that cyclohexanol above its boiling point (161.8 °C), produced enough amount of H2, which simultaneously increases the conversion of furanic compounds. Interestingly, the selectivity of corresponding alcohols was 100% for all the temperatures. So, 180 °C is the optimum reaction temperature for the transfer hydrogenation of furanic compounds to their corresponding alcohols using cyclohexanol as a hydrogen donor over CuMgO-5 catalyst. For gain more insights into the transfer hydrogenation of furanic molecules over the CuMgO-5 catalyst, kinetics studies were carried out at different temperatures (160 °C, 170 °C, and 180 °C) and the results are presented in Fig. 6 A. We assumed that the transfer hydrogenation of furanic molecules progressed as a pseudo-first-order reaction. The rate constant (k) values calculated for this reaction was 0.000733, 0.00121, and 0.00249 min−1 at 160 °C, 170 °C, and 180 °C, respectively as shown in Fig. 6A, and increased value of rate constant along with the temperature shows that reaction is dependent on temperature. The activation energy (Ea) for this reaction was calculated by the Arrhenius plot and presented in Fig. 6B, and it was found the value is 46.19 kJ/mol for CuMgO-5 catalyst. Effect of hydrogen donor In transfer hydrogenation reaction, the conversion efficiency is largely dependent on the chemical properties of the hydrogen-donor [26]. obviously, when it is easy to dislodge hydrogen atoms from a molecule, better would be its hydrogenation ability. To study the effect of hydrogen donor's efficacy, various primary alcohols (methanol, ethanol, 1-propanol,) and secondary alcohols (2-propanol, 2-butanol,) and cyclic alcohols (such as cyclopentanol and cyclohexanol) were chosen as hydrogen-donors for the hydrogenation of FL and HMF molecules. In case of primary alcohols, methanol showed higher conversion of FL and HMF (Table 2 ; entry 1) compare to other alcohols used under similar experimental condition. It was found that an increase in carbon chain length lead to decrease in the conversion of HMF and FL as shown in Table 2. On the other hand, secondary alcohols showed higher conversion of FL compare to primary alcohols. It was also observed that among secondary alcohols, branched alcohols such as 2-propanol and 2-butanol showed better activity (Table 2; entry 4 and 5) but in case of cyclic alcohols like cyclohexanol (entry 7, Table 2), HMF and FL conversion was tremendously high compare to linear alcohols. Almost 100% conversion of HMF and FL were achieved with cyclohexanol, and this most probably is due to lower oxidation potential value for cyclohexanol (Ep/2 = > 2 V) as compared to other primary and secondary alcohols [49]. It has to be noted that CuMgO-5 catalyst is found to be very selective and showed 100% selectivity for FLOL and BHMF during the transfer hydrogenation reaction. As the cyclohexanol used as solvent (excess amount) along with hydrogen donor its conversion is 5.2%. Effect of catalyst amount The effect of CuMgO-5 amount used during the transfer hydrogenation of furanic molecules was also studied, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . A blank test was conducted without using any catalyst and it was found that conversion of HMF and FL was negligible. It was observed that the conversion of both the furans was directly affected by the amount of catalyst, and the conversion was increased when catalyst amount was increased. When 0.05 g catalyst was used, the conversion of HMF and FL were 66.0% and 69.3% respectively, and the conversions were increased to ∼99% when 0.1 g CuMgO-5 catalyst was used. It was also noticed the selectivity of corresponding alcohols remained constant with different amount (0.05 g and 0.1 g) of catalyst (CuMgO-5) used during the transfer hydrogenation reaction. From the above results, the optimum catalyst amount was 0.1 g (which was equivalent to 10.0 wt% with respect to limiting reactant FL or ratio 1:10) and it provided significant amount of active sites to achieve good conversion of HMF and FL. Effect of reaction time Fig. 8 shows the effect of reaction time on the FL and HMF conversion in transfer hydrogenation reaction over CuMgO-5 catalyst. The conversion of both furans was increased sharply initially in early hours of reaction due to the availability of active sites and higher concentration of substrate. The maximum conversion of FL and HMF was 99% and 98%, respectively was achieved after the 7 h of reaction time. It has to be noted that HMF showed quite less activity towards transfer hydrogenation than FL. The selectivity remained 100% for FLOL and BHMF throughout the reaction process. Role of Cu-content and different supports Effect of Cu loading onto the support i.e. MgO have also been studied and results are summarized in Table 3 . It was observed that with the increase of Cu loading, conversion of FL and HMF increased sharply (Entry 1–4, Table 3) and 5 wt% of Cu metal loading was found optimum to achieve high conversion of both FL and HMF. 5 wt% of Cu was loaded over different supports and their activities were studied and the results are shown in Table 3. Acidic supports such as ZrO2 and Al2O3 showed the FL conversion of FL 9.5% (Entry 5, Table 3) and 10.3% (Entry 7, Table 3) respectively and it is lower compare to basic support like MgO (Entry 3,4; Table 3). Whereas the neutral support ZnO (Entry 8, Table 3) showed moderate activity (higher than the acidic support and lower than basic support) [50,51]. DFT study Overall reaction: C6H11OH(g)+C4H3CHO(g)=C6H10 O(g)+ C4H3CH2OH(g) C6H11OH(g), C4H3CHO(g), C6H10 O(g) and C4H3CH2OH(g) are cyclohexanol, furfuryl, cyclohexanone and furfuryl-alcohol, respectively. Reaction mechanism: (R1) C6H11OH(g) + C4H3CHO(g) +* = C6H11OH*+ C4H3CHO(g) (R2) C6H11OH* + C4H3CHO(g) +* = C6H11OH*+ C4H3CHO* (R3) C6H11OH* + C4H3CHO* = C6H11O* + H*+ C4H3CHO* (R4) C6H11O*+ H* + C4H3CHO* = C6H11 O* + 2H*+ C4H3CHO* (R5) C6H11 O*+2H*+C4H3CHO*=C6H11 O(g)+2H*+C4H3CHO* (R6) C6H11 O(g)+2H*+C4H3CH2OH*=C6H11 O(g)+C4H3CH2O* + H* (R7) C6H11 O(g)+2H*+C4H3CH2OH*=C6H11 O(g)+C4H3CHOH*+H* (R8) C6H11 O(g)+C4H3CH2O*+H*= C6H11 O(g)+ C4H3CH2OH* (R9) C6H11 O(g)+C4H3CHOH*+H*=C6H11 O(g) + C4H3CH2OH* (R10) C6H11 O(g)+C4H3CH2OH*=C6H11 O(g) + C4H3CH2OH(g) The cyclohexanol (C6H11OH) adsorb at the Cu(111) surface though non-bonding interaction with the Cu-O bond distance measured to be 2.28 Å (Fig. 9 (a)). The adsorption energy of cyclohexanol over Cu(111) surface was calculate to be −135.8 kJ/mol (Fig. 10 ). The adsorbed C6H11OH* undergo OH bond cleavage to form the surface adsorbed C6H11O* and H*, as shown in Fig. 9(b). Both the C6H11O* and H* surface intermediates adsorb at the three-fold hollow site, with the Cu-O and Cu-H bond distances were measured to be 2.12 Å and 1.76 Å, respectively (Fig. 9(b). The reaction energy for the OH bond dissociation was calculated to be −26.9 kJ/mol (Fig. 10). The C6H11O* intermediate further undergo CH bond dissociation to form surface adsorbed cyclohexanone (C6H10 O*) and H*, shown in Fig. 9(c), with the reaction energy of this elementary step calculated as −68.4 kJ/mol (Fig. 10). The surface adsorbed cyclohexanone (C6H10 O*) desorbed from the Cu(111) surface with the desorption energy 137.5 kJ/mol (Fig. 10). The furan molecule, Furfural (C4H3 CHO), adsorb strongly to the Cu(111) surface parallel to the surface, forming Cu-C bond (2.24 Å), shown in Fig. 11 (a). The adsorption energy of furfuryl was calculated as −163.0 kJ/mol. The first hydrogenation of the -CHO functionality of furfural may lead to two different intermediates. Hydrogenation at the C atom of CHO leads to intermediate C4H3 CH2O (Fig. 11(c)), whereas hydrogenation at the O atom of -CHO will give C4H3 CHOH intermediate (Fig. 11(d)). The C4H3 CH2O intermediate bind to the Cu(111) surface at the bridging position forming two Cu-O bonds (2.09 Å and 2.03 Å) (Fig. 11(c)). The C4H3 CHOH intermediate bind to the Cu(111) surface through C atom forming Cu-C bond (2.14 Å) as shown in Fig. 11(c). The formation of the C4H3 CH2O intermediate was found to be energetically favourable by −59.1 kJ/mol (Fig. 10) compared to the C4H3 CHOH intermediate. The reaction energy for the hydrogenation of furfural to C4H3 CH2O intermediate was calculated to be endothermic by 36.3 kJ/mol (Fig. 10). Further hydrogenation of the surface adsorbed C4H3 CH2O intermediate produce the furfuryl alcohol (C4H3 CH2OH). The reaction energy for the second hydrogenation step from C4H3 CH2O intermediate to furfuryl alcohol (C4H3 CH2OH) calculated to be exothermic by −45.9 kJ/mol (Fig. 10). The C4H3 CH2OH intermediate adsorb to the Cu(111) surface parallelly (Fig. 12 (c)) and form very strong non-bonding interaction with the Cu(111) surface (Eads ∼ −266.7 kJ/mol). The Cu-C and Cu-H bond distances were measured to be 2.46 Å and 2.27 Å, respectively (Fig. 12(c)). The product furfuryl alcohol (C4H3 CH2OH) desorb from the Cu(111) surface with desorption energy −266.7 kJ/mol (Fig. 10).To understand the effect of reaction temperature on the reaction energy profile, a free energy (E-TS) diagram for the cyclohexane-furfuryl transfer hydrogenation reaction at 180 °C has been shown in Fig. 13 . Due to the inclusion of entropy factors the adsorption and desorption energies of the reactant and product molecules were changed, as can be seen in Fig. 13. The adsorption of cyclohexanol is mild endergonic in nature (24.4 kJ/mol) due to the entropy loss of the cyclohexanol molecule upon adsorption (Fig. 13). The adsorption of furfural is still exergonic with the (E-TS) for the adoption elementary step calculated to be −64.2 kJ/mol, as can be seen in Fig. 13. The reaction energy of the elementary step involving surface adsorbed species as well as the intrinsic activation energy barriers remained unaltered as can be seen in Fig. 13. Due to the inclusion of entropy factor the desorption of the product molecules, cyclohexanone and furfuryl alcohol become more favoured. The desorption step of cyclohexanone molecule was found to be energetically favourable by −14.5 kJ/mol (Fig. 13). Similarly the desorption energy for the furfuryl alcohol decreases to 168.9 kJ/mol after adding the entropy correction, making the desorption of the adsorbed product species easy at the reaction condition. Reusability Recyclability and stability of CuMgO-5 catalyst checked through experimentation. At the end of the reaction, the solid catalyst was taken out by filtration from the reaction product during hot condition and cleaned with mixture of water and ethanol and dried at 100 °C for 6 h. This used catalyst was also pre-treated (reduced) before the next run in the flow of 10% H2 balance N2. Four catalytic runs were performed at the low conversion of furanic molecules which was in the range of 57–55% in each cycle after 4 hour of reaction, and it was almost constant after 4th recycle also (Fig. 14 ). This slight decrease in conversion was mainly due to the partial loss of Cu metal during the filtration and drying process. The amount Cu was estimated by ICP-AES and it was found that there was almost no leaching of the Cu metal during catalysis. The filtrate content < 2 ppb of Cu confirms that the CuMgO-5 catalyst is really stable during the transfer hydrogenation reaction and heterogeneous in nature. Conclusion Cu/MgO catalyst with optimum Cu particle size in nanometer range was prepared successfully where dispersion of Cu is very high. The 5 wt% Cu supported on MgO was found very active and selective in the transfer hydrogenation of biomass derived furanic molecules FL and HMF into their corresponding alcohols using cyclohexanol as a suitable hydrogen donor. During this transfer hydrogenation reaction, cyclohexanol was simultaneously converted into cyclohexanone, which is an industrially important chemical. Very high conversion (>98 %) of FL and HMF was obtained with 100 % selectivity to the corresponding alcohols after 7 h of reaction at 180 °C. DFT calculation shows that transfer hydrogenation involves two type of energy process, the endergonic which is the removal of H2 from cyclohexanol (24.4 kJ/mol) and the exergonic addition of H2 on furfural (−64.2 kJ/mol). Due to the inclusion of entropy factor, the desorption of the product molecules, cyclohexanone and furfuryl alcohol become more favoured. The catalyst can be recovered without any change in the catalytic activity even after four consecutive recycles, which showed the stability and truly heterogenous nature of the catalyst. In summary, selective hydrogenation of FL and HMF using hydrogen carrier molecules is an attractive alternative to gas-phase hydrogenation using molecular hydrogen which avoid solubility of hydrogen and mass transfer related issues. Unlike, gas-phase hydrogenation using molecular hydrogen, where excess hydrogen need to be recycled and need expensive hydrogen compressor operation, liquid hydrogen donor can facilitate simultaneous conversion of furanic molecules to corresponding alcohols and hydrogen donor molecule to corresponding dehydrogenated product. coredata.dc:description: Upgradation of biomass derived furanic molecules viz. Furfural and 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) through transfer hydrogenation using cyclohexanol as a hydrogen donor agent over CuMgO-based catalyst is reported here. CuMgO (2–10 wt% Cu loading) based catalysts were synthesized through hydrothermal route and thoroughly investigated by XRD, SEM, TEM, ICP-AES, BET-surface area, XPS, H2-TPR and DFT calculation. 5 wt% CuMgO-5 (designated as CuMgO-5) catalyst exhibited very high catalytic activity (>99% conversion of reactant) in the transfer hydrogenation of furanic molecules to corresponding alcohols with ∼100% selectivity at 180 °C after 7 h of reaction. Catalytic experiments and detailed characterization of the catalyst indicate that high Cu dispersion and the presence of metallic Cu on the MgO surface are key parameters for its high catalytic activity. Furthermore, the kinetics studies showed that the reaction is sensitive with reaction temperature. DFT calculation reveals the endergonic process of H2 removal from cyclohexanol and the exergonic process of H2 addition to carbonyl group of furanic molecules.
coredata.dc:title: Selective transfer hydrogenation of biomass derived furanic molecules using cyclohexanol as a hydrogen donor over nanostructured Cu/MgO catalyst
